newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian Exchange launches RTS index futures soon.
newsitem.headline: Russian Exchange launches RTS index futures soon.

text.p: The Russian Exchange plans to launch trading in Russian Trading System (RTS) index futures in about a week, exchange officials said.
"In a week or earlier we shall launch RTS index futures," Viktor Gorokhov, head of the exchange's futures department, told a news conference.
Russian Exchange president Alexei Vlasov said returns on RTS index futures could be much higher than the 26 percent annual yield on Russian Treasury bills.
Russian share prices have risen over 50 percent so far this year.
At the end of last year Russian Exchange launched futures trading in LUKoil, Mosenergo and Rostelekom and plans to increase the volume of trading soon.
"The interest in the market is growing," Gorokhov said.

The Russian Exchange was the main floor for trading Russian privatisation vouchers in 1992-93. Since then trading has focused more on futures on commodities and government securities, but it is trying to regain a bigger role in equities.
Average daily turnover in equities futures trading amounts to between $20 and $25 million with a record of $50 million set last Friday, he said.
"I think within three weeks daily volume will be about that," he said.
Average daily turnover on the RTS, an electronic trading system similar to NASDAQ, and Russia's main market for equities trading, is $50 million, with recent records over $70 million.
Gorokhov said the exchange also planned to increase trade volume by cutting terms of the contract from the current one month to half a month.
Futures trading is becoming more attractive for many Russian investors, especially banks, who are considering higher-risk investments such as equities as the yield on low-risk T-bills falls.

Stocks department head Maxim Belousov said the Russian Exchange launched spot trading in LUKoil, Rostelekom and Mosenergo shares last week and on Friday launched trading in Moscow city bonds. --Julie Tolkacheva, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520
